properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong winter storm will impact the BC interior with snow beginning this evening. The approaching storm will give widespread snow into the interior this evening. The main band of snow will shift northwards on Friday morning, allowing the snow to come to an end for communities in the Okanagan and South Thompson. Snow will continue in the Kootenays, Columbias, as well as the central and northern interior. In addition there is a chance of freezing rain for the central interior as the band of snow pushes northwards on Friday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T14:14:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T22:15:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2180845932.2020
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong Pacific storm is on the way for this afternoon and Friday for the BC coast. The storm will approach the coast today. Precipitation has begun over Vancouver Island and will spread to the south coast early this afternoon. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop this afternoon. Initially temperatures will be cold enough to allow some of the precipitation to start as wet snow over Vancouver Island and higher elevations of the south coast. By this evening warm air accompanying the storm will drive freezing levels and temperatures higher so that precipitation changes to rain for most communities. The exception may be Whistler and the Sea to Sky Highway from Squamish to Whistler where snow could persist longer. The heavy rain and strong winds continue all day on Friday. The highest rainfall amounts will be over the central coast, north and west Vancouver Island. Areas of Squamish, northern sections of Metro Vancouver, and the Fraser Valley will also see significant amounts of rainfall. In areas where snow does accumulate, a higher chance of localized flooding is possible due to rain on snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T10:55:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T18:56:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3527785076.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A Pacific warm front is giving snow to the northern sections of East Vancouver Island. At 5 pm, 5 cm of snow had been reported near Campbell River Airport. Total snow accumulations up to 10 cm can be expected over inland sections before the snow changes to rain late this evening. However, near the water, snow will be mixed with rain and no significant accumulations are expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T09:16:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T01:25:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2636723961.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Amber Alert
properties.Summary:
Expires: 2020-01-02T19:45:00-03:30
Originated from CAP Alert: FES-NL, 2020-01-02T19:44:53-03:30, 824A2081-24CA-5E3A-7D24-B503B83737AA
Area: The Royal Newfoundland Constabulary in Corner Brook have issued an Amber Alert for 12 year old Tony Austin “Aussie” GREENHAM who was abducted by his father Tony GREEHAM. Both were last seen on Thursday, January 2, 2020 at 9:45 am. Tony Austin “Aussie” GREENHAM DOB: 2007-09-11 is described as being 5’1” tall, 140 lbs, with brown eyes and brown short hair. Tony GREENHAM is 47 years old, 5’7” tall, 252lbs and has blue eyes, a bald head, and a grey goatee. They are believed to be travelling in a black 2009 Ford Escape NL plate: JEL 275. Anyone with information pertaining to the location of either person or the vehicle is asked to contact police at 709-637-4100, or at 911 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-TIPS (8477). You can also provide information anonymously on the NL Crime Stoppers website at www.nl.crimestopppers.com
properties.Author: FES-NL

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. A cold front tracking NW to SE through southwest Saskatchewan is bringing a short blast of snow, strong wind gusts of 60 km/h or greater, and blowing snow to the area this evening. As the front passes winds will shift to the northwest and visibilities will be reduced to near-zero at times in blowing snow. Conditions will improve later this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T02:35:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T23:27:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2175735917.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 20 cm is expected. An approaching winter storm will spread snow to the B.C. Peace Friday. Snow at times heavy will begin Friday morning across the B.C. Peace region. Snowfall amounts near 10 cm are generally expected, however, the snow will be heavier near the Rockies, including Chetwynd and Hudson Hope, where 20 cm are forecast. Snow will continue through Friday night then should end shortly past midnight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T14:29:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T22:30:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1425787199.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog has developed along the north shore of Lake Superior this afternoon and will persist into early evening. Additionally, there is a risk of freezing drizzle today with temperatures remaining near the freezing mark. Untreated surfaces could become icy particularly where temperatures are below freezing. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T04:31:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T19:33:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2795337379.2020
Area: Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. An approaching winter storm will spread snow to the northern interior tonight through Friday. Snow at times heavy will begin this evening across the Bulkley Valley, McGregor, and Williston regions. Snow will continue through Friday with snowfall amounts of up to 20 to 25 cm by Friday evening. Meanwhile Highway 97 - Pine Pass will see snow beginning tonight with up to 25 cm of snow by Friday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T15:49:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T23:50:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4250827090.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A strong Pacific storm will bring snow tonight and Friday. Up to 25 cm of snow is expected by Friday morning. Warm air moving inland will cause the snow to change to rain on Friday. Moderate rain is expected through the day, before it changes back to snow Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T16:08:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:09:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0288914289.2020
Area: Central Coast - inland sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 25 to 30 cm is expected. A strong Pacific storm is on the way for this afternoon and Friday for the BC coast. The storm will approach the coast today. Precipitation will spread onto the north coast late this afternoon. The airmass will be cold enough to produce snow for North Coast - inland including Kitimat and Terrace. The snow will intensify this evening and persist through Friday. It will eventually taper off gradually or become mixed with rain Friday night or Saturday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T04:44:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T12:45:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2175014836.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Snow and blowing snow due to strong northeasterly winds of 40 km/h gusting to 60 will continue to bring poor visibilities to Old Crow this evening. Conditions are still expected to improve tonight as the winds begin to ease and the snow tapers off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T13:59:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T23:41:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4246396583.2020
Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow are expected. A strong Pacific storm for tonight and Friday with 30 to 60 cm of snow expected over inland sections of the north coast. Snow will begin this evening for inland sections of the north coast and will intensify tonight. The snow is expected to ease and become mixed with rain Friday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T16:38:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:39:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3361954016.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of severely cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chills of -55 to -65 are forecast to continue tonight and throughout the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T12:22:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T20:23:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3627584574.2020
Area: Resolute, Grise Fiord
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A strong pacific frontal system will cross Vancouver Island tonight and tomorrow. Rain has already begun over eastern Vancouver Island, and is expected to intensify tonight. Sections of eastern Vancouver Island between Qualicum Beach and Fanny Bay will see near 50 mm of rain by Friday afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T16:09:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:10:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3828187590.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An approaching Pacific frontal system is giving light rain to the south coast. The rain may be briefly mixed with wet snow this afternoon. Rain will intensify this evening and persist through Friday. During that period, we expect 60 to 80 mm of rain to fall over Howe Sound and Metro Vancouver - central and North Shore. Heavy rain will ease Friday night but light rain or showers will continue into Saturday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T11:27:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T19:28:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2313829603.2020
Area: Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of severely cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chills of -55 to -65 are forecast to continue tonight and throughout the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T12:22:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T20:23:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1565753888.2020
Area: Cambridge Bay, Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system tracking through the Yukon is giving periods of strong easterly winds and snow to the Dempster Highway (from the Richardson to the Ogilvie Mountains). The strong winds combined with falling snow will continue to give blizzard conditions through early this evening. Blizzard conditions will improve this evening as the winds begin to ease. Easterly winds will reintensify near the Richardson mountains Friday afternoon. Blizzard conditions near the Richardson mountains are expected to redevelop late Friday afternoon and continue into Saturday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T15:38:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T23:39:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1817137181.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A strong Pacific storm is impacting the BC coast tonight. Precipitation has begun over Vancouver Island and the Central Coast. The rain will be mixed with wet snow this evening. Rain will persist through Friday. During that period, we expect 100 to 150 mm of rain for the Central Coast - coastal sections, West Vancouver Island and near Port Alice on North Vancouver Island. Heavy rain will ease Friday night but light rain will continue into Saturday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T16:44:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:45:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0288509949.2020
Area: North Vancouver Island, West Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. A cold front tracking NW to SE through southwest Saskatchewan is bringing a short blast of snow, strong wind gusts of 60 km/h or greater, and blowing snow to the area this evening. As the front passes winds will shift to the northwest and visibilities will be reduced to near-zero at times in blowing snow. Conditions will improve later this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T04:35:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:06:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3156248443.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An approaching Pacific frontal system is giving light rain to the south coast. The rain may be briefly mixed with wet snow early this evening. Rain will intensify late this evening and persist through Friday. During that period, we expect 60 to 80 mm of rain to fall over Howe Sound, central and northeast Metro Vancouver, and the North Shore. Heavy rain will ease Friday night but light rain or showers will continue into Saturday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T16:03:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:04:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3861478126.2020
